value.title: Tesla’s main self-driving rival isn’t Google—it’s Intel’s Mobileye
value.excerpt: Mobileye's self-driving strategy has a number of things in common with that of Tesla, the world's most valuable automaker. Like Tesla, Mobileye is aiming to gradually evolve its current driver-assistance technology into a fully self-driving system.

value.title: China’s Megvii kick-starts IPO on Shanghai’s Star Market after Trump added facial recognition giant to entity list
value.excerpt: Facial-recognition developer Megvii abandoned its original Hong Kong IPO plan after the Trump administration placed it on a trade blacklist; it is now looking to list on Shanghai’s Star Market.

value.title: LA Police Commission Adopts Oversight Measures for Facial Recognition Tool
value.excerpt: The LAPD’s promise of robust oversight for facial recognition technology in police work hasn’t quelled concerns from civil liberties groups that the tools will perpetuate harm in communities of

value.title: Job Screening Service Halts Facial Analysis of Applicants
value.excerpt: HireVue, a leading provider of software for vetting job candidates based on an algorithmic assessment, said Tuesday it is killing off a controversial feature of its software: analyzing a person’s facial expressions in a video to discern certain characteristics.

value.title: The best tech of CES 2021
value.excerpt: In order to find the best products from CES 2021, we met with manufacturers big and small for in-depth briefings, compared these gadgets to our top tested picks in terms of specs and features and, in some cases,

value.title: Roboflow raises $2.1M for its end-to-end computer vision platform
value.excerpt: Roboflow, a startup that aims to simplify the process of building computer vision models, today announced that it has raised a $2.1 million seed round co-led by Lachy Groom and Craft Ventures. Additional investors include Segment co-founder Calvin French-Owen,

value.title: Programming tweak helps AI software imitate human visual learning
value.excerpt: Using a novel programming tweak, a pair of neuroscientists have managed to replicate human visual learning in computer-based artificial intelligence.

value.title: A Startup Will Nix Algorithms Built on Ill-Gotten Facial Data
value.excerpt: San Francisco face-recognition startup Everalbum won a $2 million contract with the Air Force to provide “AI-driven access control.” Monday, another arm of the US government dealt the company a setback.

value.title: The US Army is developing a nightmarish thermal facial recognition system
value.excerpt: The US Army just took a giant step toward developing killer robots that can see and identify faces in the dark. DEVCOM, the US Army’s corporate research department, last week published a pre-print paper documenting the development of an image database for training AI to perform facial recognition using thermal images.

value.title: Ever app settles FTC allegations it trained facial recognition tech with users' photos
value.excerpt: The developer of Ever, a photo storage and backup app that shut down in August, settled US Federal Trade Commission allegations that it "deceived consumers about its use of facial recognition technology and its retention of the photos and videos of users who deactivated their accounts,

value.title: Samsung reveals smarter Family Hub fridge and a robo-vac that thinks it’s a guard dog
value.excerpt: Samsung’s big Galaxy S21 launch may be coming later this week, but it’s home appliances which are getting their moment in the spotlight today. Fresh for CES 2021 are updates in the

value.title: CES Liveblog: Smart Home, Workout Tech, and So Many TVs
value.excerpt: The consumer tech show is virtual this year, and the WIRED Gear crew is watching all the Zooms to bring you up-to-the-minute highlights of news from CES.

value.title: Ambarella unveils 8K AI vision processor for car, drone, and robot cameras
value.excerpt: Ambarella has unveiled the CV5 AI Vision Processor to handle 8K image processing for car, consumer, crone, and robot cameras.

value.title: Outlandish Stanford facial recognition study claims there are links between facial features and political orientation
value.excerpt: A controversial study from Stanford-affiliated researchers claims to find links between facial features and political affiliation.

value.title: Agdhi to use machine learning and computer vision in agriculture
value.excerpt: Agdhi will use machine learning, computer vision, edge computing and spectral imaging techniques to detect the defects in seeds and crops

value.title: Intel launches facial recognition solution amid debate around the tech’s biases
value.excerpt: Intel has launched a facial recognition solution, which will work with smart locks, access control, point-of-sale, ATMs, and kiosks

value.title: Police Use of Clearview AI's Facial Recognition Tech Spiked After Capitol Raid
value.excerpt: Clearview AI’s controversial facial-recognition app has seen a spike in use as police track down the pro-Trump insurgents who descended on the Capitol on Wednesday. With so many of those idiots snapping selfies and livestreaming the raid as if it was a school field trip,

value.title: Neural Networks Playing Video Games Teach Us About Our Own Brains
value.excerpt: When you are driving a car, your brain is taking in an enormous amount of visual information and using it to make driving decisions, such as when to brake

value.title: How far can facial recognition go in finding rioters in DC?
value.excerpt: Photos and videos from the riot are all over the internet, and law enforcement can use them to help find criminals; but one face doesn't make the case.

value.title: How far can facial recognition go in finding rioters in DC?
value.excerpt: Photos and videos from the riot are all over the internet, and law enforcement can use them to help find criminals; but one face doesn't make the case.

value.title: Is neuroscience the key to protecting AI from adversarial attacks?
value.excerpt: Deep neural networks are a key component of computer vision applications, from video editors to medical software and self-driving cars.

value.title: Nope, ‘facial recognition’ didn’t spot Antifa members at US riots
value.excerpt: The facial recognition firm behind Congressman Gaetz's claim says it actually identified neo-Nazis -- not Antifa.

value.title: Ai In Computer Vision Market 2020 Insights, Revenue, Price and Gross Margin, Forecast 2023
value.excerpt: The improved computing capabilities of processors are paving the way for the future growth in the AI in computer vision market. The AI In Computer Vision Market is estimated to record a significant growth throughout the forecast period.

value.title: Orlando Police End Test Of Amazon's Real-Time Facial 'Rekognition' System
value.excerpt: The city of Orlando, Fla., says it has ended a pilot program in which its police force used Amazon's real-time facial recognition — a system called "Rekognition" that had triggered complaints from rights and privacy groups when its use was revealed ...

value.title: Intel Launches RealSense ID, An On-Device Facial Recognition System
value.excerpt: Intel has launched RealSense ID, a new on-device facial recognition system that uses the company's RealSense 3D technology.

value.title: NEC says new facial recognition system isn't stopped by masks
value.excerpt: NEC says face masks aren't an obstacle to its facial recognition tech. The Japanese company (via Reuters) claims its new facial recognition system can identify people with face masks in less than one second,

value.title: Seoul Robotics: A 3D Vision Of The Future
value.excerpt: Seoul Robotics leverages LiDAR 3D vision to make robots intelligent and enable autonomous systems from smart cities to smart factories

value.title: Masks no obstacle for new NEC facial recognition system
value.excerpt: Japan's NEC Corp has launched a facial recognition system that identifies people even when they are wearing masks, adapting to a new normal where face coverings have become a key form of protection against the spread of the coronavirus.

value.title: Intel's new RealSense ID packs on-device facial recognition
value.excerpt: Intel's new RealSense ID will cost $99 and launch in Q1 2021 with built-in anti-spoofing technology protecting your data.

value.title: Intel is using its RealSense tech for facial recognition
value.excerpt: Intel has found another use for its RealSense depth-sensing camera. It married the tech with a neural network to develop a facial recognition system that can enable access to the likes of smart locks and ATMs with only a glance.
